table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the sound, and not to any letter or glyph.
Namnet på ett ljud, inte en skriven bokstav eller glyf.

table.name: mem
table.column: Both {'ab:v:1,nolink} and {'aD:v} mean "have a length of", but they are used in different contexts. {'ab:v:1,nolink} is used for long items and to express height. The object of {'ab:v:1,nolink} is the length or height of the subject.

In anatomy, abduction refers to moving away from a midline. In particular, abduction at the shoulder means raising the arms up, an action which is often done to measure the length of something. Its counterpart, adduction, refers to movement towards a midline.

▶ {wej 'ujmey 'ab 'oy'naQ.:sen:nolink} "Painstiks are a little over one meter long."[1] ▶ {jav 'ujmey 'ab SuvwI'.:sen:nolink} "The warrior is six ujs tall." (about 6'10")[2] ▶ {vagh 'ujmey vI'ab.:sen:nolink} "I'm five ujs tall." (about 5'8")[2] ▶ {wej 'uj 'ab naQjej.:sen:nolink} "the spear is three uj long" (about 3'5")[2] ▶ {loSmaH jav vI' Soch loS 'uj 'ab meH:sen:nolink} "Bridge Height: 16.28 M"[3] ▶ {HIvtaHvIS toQDuj cha'vatlh wejmaH Soch vI' vagh chorgh 'uj 'ab 'oH:sen:nolink} "Attack Formation Height: 82.75 M"[3] ▶ {qughtaHvIS toQDuj HutmaH vI' jav wa' 'uj 'ab 'oH:sen:nolink} "Cruise Formation Height: 31.56 M"[3] ▶ {SaqtaHvIS toQDuj wa'vatlh loS vI' jav chorgh 'uj 'ab 'oH:sen:nolink} "Landing Formation Height: 36.46 M"[3]
length, height, long, high, have a length of, have a height of

table.name: mem
table.column: When used to specify location (as opposed to linear dimension), the object of this verb is expressed in {lawrI'(mey):n@@lawrI':n, -mey:n}, so {X 'ab:sen:nolink} could be translated as "be at latitude X".[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: but, nevertheless, even so, however, whereas
اما، با این حال، حتی در همین حال، در حالی که [AUTOTRANSLATED]
men, ändå, dock, trots allt, emellertid
但是、儘管如此、然而、儘管如此 [AUTOTRANSLATED]
mas, no entanto, mesmo assim, enquanto
mais néanmoins, quand même, alors que [AUTOTRANSLATED]
This was defined as "but, nevertheless, even so, however" in {TKD:src}. The definition "whereas" for expressing contrast was added at {qep'a' 25 (2018):src}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The Beatles song "Tomorrow Never Knows" contains the lyric "surrender to the void" ({jegh:v} "surrender" + {cha':n:num} "two").
The example which came with the request is about outer space, so this seems to be a scientific term rather than a philosophical term.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the block used in blacksmithing, and not to the bone in the ear.[1]
The Acme Corporation makes the anvils which are frequently dropped on Wile E. Coyote.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This was originally defined as "vein" in {TKD:src}, and subsequently expanded to mean "blood vessel" in general.
A German word for "vein" is "Ader".

table.name: mem
table.column: Both {'aD:v:nolink} and {'ab:v:1} mean "have a length of", but they are used slightly differently. For flat objects such as tabletops, {'aD:v:nolink} is used for one dimension while {juch:v:1} is used for the other. For long objects, and for height, {'ab:v:1,nolink} is used instead.[2]

In anatomy, abduction refers to moving away from a midline. In particular, abduction at the shoulder means raising the arms up, an action which is often done to measure the length of something. Its counterpart, adduction, refers to movement towards a midline.
▶ {wejvatlh loSmaH loS vI' vagh wej 'uj 'aD Duj:sen:nolink} "Length: 120 M"[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: The English translation of the sentence from {Star Trek Constellations:src} does not appear in the book, but in the author's annotations which was a separate document.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a device for preventing the overloading of an electrical circuit.[1]
The lyrics to the Beatles song "When I'm Sixty Four" contains the phrase "mending a fuse".

table.name: mem
table.column: {'arHa':sen:nolink} is the Klingon name of Klingonist John Harness.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is also used for random numbers, such as when throwing dice ({mI' nagh:n}). See {'al:v:2}.
Muhammad Ali said to "float like a butterfly and sting like a bee".

The fact that this can be used adjectivally for numbers[2] suggests that it is a stative verb, but it is not out of the question that maybe it can be used adjectivally only for numbers but can take an object otherwise.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is just the verb {'al:v:1} applied to numbers.
Det här är bara verbet {'al:v:1} använt på siffror.

Based on the explanation and the examples, this is a stative verb. However, the definition of {'al:v:1:nolink} as "float (in/on air)" rather than "be floating" leaves open the possibility that it can take an object in other contexts.

table.name: mem
table.column: Backwards of {Qugh la':n@@Qugh:n:2, la':n}. Kirk calls Kruge a "Klingon bastard" in {Star Trek III:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Alnilam is the star in the middle of Orion's belt.

table.name: mem
table.column: The request was "freckle(s)" so this is how it may appear in other word lists, but the "(s)" has been removed here for consistency with other definitions.

table.name: mem
table.column: yxa med med spets i änden
eräs ase; kirves, jonka päässä on piikki

table.name: mem
table.column: In the International Phonetic Alphabet, the exclamation mark is the symbol for the alveolar click.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an informal term for the old-fashioned contraption that resembles an umbrella. A more technical term is unknown. An apparatus that creates a force field to counter gravity is a {tlham rI'gheS:n}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
The definition is given as "glass", in a list of materials.
"Aluminum oxynitride" is the ceramic known as "transparent aluminum".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a specialized school.[2] (For the most general word for a place of learning, see {DuSaQ:n}.)
This is a reference to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (AMPAS).

table.name: mem
table.column: Irma was the main character of the 1957 play "The Balcony".

table.name: mem
table.column: 花哨, 華而不實, 浮誇 [AUTOTRANSLATED]
prameus, räikeys, röyhkeys, pröystäilevyys, huomiota herättävyys
This is typically used as the object of the verbs {'ang:v}, {'agh:v}, {chIw:v}, and the like, but it's not restricted to those.[1]
"Gaudeamus igitur" is a song commonly sung or performed at university graduation ceremonies in some European countries.
pramea, räikeä, röyhkeä, pröystäilevä, huomiota herättävä

table.name: mem
table.column:
This can be used for when someone sacrifices forces for a certain goal or just wastes their resources.[1]
Most Klingon lexicographers consider this and {'an:v:2} to be two homophonous words, but historically, the "be a waste" meaning developed out of the "be petrified" meaning, perhaps because something loses any original use it may have had if it is turned to stone.[3]

This was revealed to express "it's such a waste", as one might say if one sees an almost full bottle of cola in the garbage. It was defined as "waste [as someone sacrifices forces for a certain goal or just wastes one's resources]" in the KLI new words list in 2018, but as a verb.[1] Some people found this to be confusing (believing that it can take an object), and Dr. Okrand was asked for clarification. At the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a':src} a few months later, Dr. Okrand recorded a {video:url:http://youtu.be/f2cgPd-TBJE&start=229} explaining the usage, revising the definition to "be a waste" (noting that to "waste" something, with an object, is {'anmoH:v}).[2] Some people felt that this was still unclear, so at the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a':src} after that (in 2019), the homophonous {'an:v:2} was revealed, and an explanation was given about how these verbs were historically related.[3]
The German definition "Verschwendung sein" comes from the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2019:src} booklet.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: See under {'an:v:1} for an explanation of the history of this word.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is used to talk about fossils. Most Klingon lexicographers consider this and {'an:v:1} to be two homophonous words, but historically, the "be a waste" meaning developed out of the "be petrified" meaning, perhaps because something loses any original use it may have had if it is turned to stone.
When applied to people, it can only mean literal turning to stone. (It does not mean "really scared" as "petrified" does in English.)
The German definition comes from the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2019:src} booklet.

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Federation. Also called {'anDorya':n:nolink}. Not to be confused with the country on Earth called {'anDo'ra':n}.
Eräs Yhdistyneiden planeettojen liiton ({yuQjIjQa':n}) perustajajäsenistä. Kutsutaan myös nimellä {'anDorya':n:nolink}. Ei pidä sekoittaa Maan valtioon nimeltä {'anDo'ra':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word has not explicitly appeared in canon, but is implied to exist by {'anDor:n} and {'anDorya'ngan:n}, and the variations in planet names described in {KGT p.141-142:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a chemical compound which reacts to create an explosion when combined with {yuryum:n}.
[1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - Magic to Make the Sanest Man Go Mad:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a name from {wIlyam SeQpIr:n:name}'s play {'antonI' tlhI'yopatra' je:sen:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran vegetable.

table.name: mem
table.column: The same word is used for fossils of plants, bones, etc.
Rhona Fenwick is a Klingon speaker who is an archeologist.

table.name: mem
table.column: نشان می دهد، نشان می دهد [AUTOTRANSLATED]
This verb can be used colloquially to express the definition of a word within the same language (but not when translating). See {ghaS:v}.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: 'ang'eghQo' quv Hutlhbogh jagh neH ghobtaHvIS ghaH.
Only an enemy without honor refuses to show himself in battle.
Nur ein Gegner ohne Ehre zeigt sein Gesicht nicht während des Kampfes.
تنها یک دشمن بدون احترام حاضر به نشان دادن خود در نبرد نیست. [AUTOTRANSLATED]
Endast en fiende utan ära vägrar att visa sig i strid. [AUTOTRANSLATED]
Только враг без чести отказывается показывать себя в бою. [AUTOTRANSLATED]
只有沒有榮譽的敵人才會拒絕在戰鬥中展示自己。 [AUTOTRANSLATED]
Apenas um inimigo sem honra recusa se mostrar em batalha.
Vain vihollinen, jolla ei ole kunniaa, kieltäytyy paljastamasta itseään taistelussa.
Seul un ennemi sans honneur refuse de se montrer au combat. [AUTOTRANSLATED]
Only an enemy without honour refuses to show himself in battle.

table.name: mem
table.column: an individual member of the Kos'Karii
eräs myyttinen käärmeen kaltainen eläin, kos'karii
The Latin word for eel is "anguilla".

table.name: mem
table.column: Arthur Philip Dent is the protagonist of {The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the general term for a small container.[3]

This word was originally used to translated "Limited Edition" for {Klingon Monopoly:src}, as {'aplo'mey puS neH chenmoHlu'pu':sen:nolink}, before {'aplo':n:nolink} was changed to {vey:n}. The Klingon version of the list of the game box's "contents" also has the heading {ngaS 'aplo':sen:nolink}.
Perhaps a reference to the Apollo Lunar Sample Return Container from the Apollo 11 mission.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the metallic chemical element with the symbol Ca and atomic number 20.

table.name: mem
table.column: um pássaro parecido com um falcão
un oiseau ressemblant à un faucon [AUTOTRANSLATED]
This is a particular kind of {toQ:n} which flies particularly fast.
"Apus" is the Latin name for the birds commonly known as swifts.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This refers to predicting based on deductive reasoning or research or science.
Note that weather forecasts (see {muD Dotlh:n}) tend to use {'e' -lu':sen@@'e':n, -lu':v} over {net:n}, but using {net:n:nolink} would not be wrong.

Dies bezieht sich auf eine Vorhersage, die auf wissenschaftliche Erkenntnisse basiert.
Man beachte dass es bei der Wettervorhersage (siehe {muD Dotlh:n}) üblich ist {'e' -lu:sen@@'e':n, -lu':v} anstatt {net:n} zu sagen, aber {net:n:nolink} zu verwenden wäre nicht falsch.
The word for "reason" or "intellect" in Arabic is "'aql".

▶ {SIS 'e' vI'aq:sen@@SIS:v, 'e':n, vI-:v, 'aq:v} "I forecast/predict (that it will) rain." ▶ {SIS 'e' 'aqlu':sen@@SIS:v, 'e':n, 'aq:v, -lu':v} "it is predicted that it will rain" ▶ {SIS 'e' 'aqlu'bej:sen@@SIS:v, 'e':n, 'aq:v, -lu':v, -bej:v} "it is predicted with certainty that it will rain" ▶ {SISbe' 'e' 'aqlu'bej:sen@@SIS:v, -be':v, 'e':n, 'aq:v, -lu':v, -bej:v} "it is predicted with certainty that it will not rain" ▶ {SIS 'e' 'aqlu'law':sen@@SIS:v, 'e':n, 'aq:v, -lu':v, -law':v} "it would appear that it will rain, it seems that it will rain" ▶ {ghaytan SIS 'e' 'aqlu':sen@@ghaytan:adv, SIS:v, 'e':n, 'aq:v, -lu':v} "it's likely that it will rain" ▶ {SIS 'e' 'aqlu', javmaH vatlhvI' DIch:sen@@SIS:v, 'e':n, 'aq:v, -lu':v, jav:n:1,num, maH:n:2,num, vatlhvI':n, DIch:n} "it is predicted that it will rain, 60% certainty", or "there's a 60% chance it will rain"

table.name: mem
table.column: type of weapon (half ax, half bat'leth)
ett slags vapen (hälften yxa, hälften bat'leth)
tipo de arma (meio machado, meio bat'leth)

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a general purpose knife that seems to be able to cut through anything.
The phrase "Act now!" is used repeatedly in TV informercials for Ginsu knives.

table.name: mem
table.column: bottom surface of a table, ceiling
superfície inferior de uma mesa, teto
yläosan alaosa, pöydän alapinta, katon alapinta

The other face of an object's {'aqroS:n:1,nolink} is its {yor:n}.[1]
This word can be used to refer to a ceiling, though the terms {pa' beb:n} and {rav'eq:n} (which depend on whether there are any floors above it) are more common.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is used to specify a limit or restriction.
In other contexts, consider using the verb suffix {-qu':v}. For example: {nom yIghoSqu'!:sen}
"Across". It's unclear why {'aqroS:n:2,nolink} seems to precede the noun while {rav:n:2,nolink} seems to follow the noun.
▶ {'aqroS qughDo:sen:nolink}: {pIvlob Hut vI' vagh:sen:nolink} "Maximum Cruising Speed - Warp 9.5"[1] ▶ {Qapchu'meH 'aqroS chuq:n:nolink} "maximum effective range"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: A character in a famous Klingon opera.
En roll i en känd klingonsk opera.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the trailing or climbing plant itself.

"Luffa acutangula" is a type of gourd known as vegetable gourd or Chinese okra. In the episode {TOS - The Apple:src}, a character named Akuta smashes a Persian melon.
The request was for the plant. Presumably, the fruit be {'aquta' naH:n@@'aquta':n, naH:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Ak'voh, act of watching over a fallen warrior's body
Betrachten des Körpers eines gefallen Kriegers
عمل تماشای یک بدن جنگجو افتاده [AUTOTRANSLATED]
agera att titta över en fallen krigare kropp [AUTOTRANSLATED]
акт наблюдения за телом павшего воина [AUTOTRANSLATED]
看著墮落的戰士身體的行為 [AUTOTRANSLATED]
ato de vigiar o corpo de um guerreiro caído
Ak'voh, acte de veiller sur le corps d'un guerrier tombé au combat [AUTOTRANSLATED]

This is an ancient tradition where the comrades of a warrior who had died in battle stayed with the body to keep away predators, which allowed the spirit ({qa':n}) to leave the body when it was ready for the journey to Sto-Vo-Kor ({Suto'vo'qor:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column:
This question word follows the noun to which it refers, which never has a plural suffix.[1]
Grammatically, a plural prefix is used if the questioned noun can be singular or plural and the translation is "how many?" A singular prefix is used if the questioned noun is something that can't be counted and the translation is "how much?"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: The ivy belongs to the genus "Hedera".

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the most common of several ways of asking for the time in Klingon. One can also ask, {'arlogh wab Qoylu'pu'?:sen:nolink} or {qen 'arlogh Qoylu'pu'?:sen:nolink} The answer to this question is, for example, {cha'logh Qoylu'pu':sen:nolink} "It has been heard twice", meaning "two o'clock".
The Federation's 24-hour system ({tera' poH:n}) is sometimes used in interplanetary communication. When working within this system, the way to ask for the time is to issue the command, {rep yIper!:sen:nolink} In replying to this command, the hours are not counted, but rather numbered from 1 to 24. For example, {tera' rep cha':sen:nolink} or {rep cha':sen:nolink} is "two o'clock". When context is clear, {tera':n} may be left out.

The sentence {vagh rep bImejnIS:sen:nolink} "Checkout time is 5 a.m." is heard in {Conversational Klingon:src} (released in 1992), with no explanation of why {vagh rep:n@@vagh:n:1, rep:n} means what it means. According to the time-telling system actually described on that tape, "5 a.m." should've been {vaghvatlh rep:sen:nolink}.
▶ {mamejDI' 'arlogh Qoylu'pu'?:sen@@ma-:v, mej:v, -DI':v, 'arlogh Qoylu'pu'?:sen} "What time do we leave?"

table.name: mem
table.column: This is not the same as {QapmIw:n:nolink}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to inheritance in the sense that if a father dies, his son inherits his possessions.

table.name: mem
table.column: A reference to the episode {DS9 - The Siege of AR-558:src} ({'at:n}, {ray:n}), and maybe also to the Siege of Troy.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is typically found on the feet of some sort of Klingon animal or on Klingon trees. In non-scientific, everyday speech, this seems to function as a general term for "fungus".[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: When an escaped prisoner looks for a guard, he always finds one.
Ein entflohener Gefangener, der nach einem Wächter sucht, wird immer einen finden.
هنگامی که یک زندانی فراری به دنبال یک نگهبان است، او همیشه یکی را پیدا می کند. [AUTOTRANSLATED]
När en flyktig fångare letar efter en vakt finner han alltid en. [AUTOTRANSLATED]
Когда сбежавший заключенный ищет охранника, он всегда находит его. [AUTOTRANSLATED]
當逃脫的囚犯尋找警衛時，他總能找到一個。 [AUTOTRANSLATED]
Quando um prisioneiro escapado procura um guarda, ele sempre encontra um.
Kun paennut vanki etsii vartijaa, hän aina löytää sellaisen.
Lorsqu'un évadé cherche un gardien, il en trouve toujours un. [AUTOTRANSLATED]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to passing through matter, as ghosts, phased lifeforms, or particles may do.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is a type of beverage made from (among other things) the {melchoQ:n} of a {teghbat:n}. It has a superficial resemblance to Terran root beer.[1, p.95]
This word refers not to a specific drink, but to a narrow class of related drinks.[2]
"A&W" is a brand of root beer.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the sound, not the musical notation.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: musical note (written notation for specific sound)
Musiknote (schriftliche Notation für einen bestimmten Klang)
نت موسیقی (نت نویسی برای صدای خاص) [AUTOTRANSLATED]
musikalisk not (skriven notation för specifikt ljud) [AUTOTRANSLATED]
音符（特定聲音的書面符號） [AUTOTRANSLATED]
nota musical (notação escrita para som específico) [AUTOTRANSLATED]
note de musique (notation écrite pour un son spécifique) [AUTOTRANSLATED]
This is a written musical note referring to a specific note (such as {yu:n} or {bIm:n}).[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
"Ow".
The example from {CK:src} literally means "My eyes sting me", which shows that {'aw':v:nolink} can take an object.

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to float in/on water or other liquids. For something floating freely in space, see {rIjHa':v}.
Floaters are found in the vitreous of the eye.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the closest Klingon equivalent, and is quite similar.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be used for any kind of building element, construction part, or even Lego pieces.[3] It can also refer to sections of a book.[4]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a collection of textual and/or visual materials organized together. It refers to the information, and not to the medium in which it is stored. It does not refer to a collection of other things (such as toys).[1]
Manila folders are made from the abacá plant.
